metadata.title: Parallel Texts in the Hebrew Bible, New Methods and Visualizations

sections.text: In this article we develop an algorithm for recognizing parallel passages in the Masoretic text of the Hebrew Bible. Results are presented online and chapters in the Hebrew Bible that contain parallel passages can be viewed synoptically. Differences between parallel passages are highlighted. Similarly, the MT Isaiah is presented synoptically with 1QIsaiah. We also examine how to examine the degree of similarity between parallel passages using a case study of 2 Kings 19-25 and their parallels in Isaiah, Jeremiah and 2 Chronicles. Keywords Hebrew Bible, parallel texts, linguistic dates, visualizations

sections.heading: 1. INTRODUCTION
sections.text: The reuse of texts is a well-known phenomenon in the Hebrew Bible. For example, in the Book of Genesis we find various allusions to older Mesopotamian texts in the Tales of the Flood [Hello, 2003: 458-460]. There are also many instances of inner biblical intertextuality, such as the references to the story of Jacob and Esau in Hosea 1, and of course there are numerous reformulations of the Hebrew Bible in later ancient literature, such as the Genesis Apocrypha and the Book of Jubilees, also called "Rewritten Scripture" [Parry and Tov, 2004]. In this article we focus on parallel texts within the Hebrew Bible. There is a lot of literature on this subject, but there is no open source online tool to search for parallel texts and with which it is possible to present these parallel texts synoptically and onlinear.

sections.heading: 2. PARALLEL PASSAGES AND LINGUISTIC VARIATION IN BIBLICAL HEBREW
sections.text: Parallel passages in the Hebrew Bible play an important role in the reconstruction of the development and growth of biblical texts, and also in the study of linguistic variation in the Hebrew language, they are often used to explain diachronic changes. Most studies of diachronism in biblical-Hebrew, archaic biblical-Hebrew, early biblical-Hebrew, and late biblical-Hebrew texts are found in several poems in the Hebrew Bible [Sáenz-Badillos, 1993: 56-62] [Notary, 2013]; the books of Pentateuch and Former Prophets 4 are the best examples of early biblical-Hebrew and the so-called core-late books [Sáenz-Badilás, 1993: 56-62].

sections.heading: 3.1 Open source tools
sections.text: An important prerequisite for the use of digital methods in scientific research is that they must not reduce the transparency of the way hypotheses are confirmed or discarded. Calculations that lead to new results should also be replicable by other scientists. Therefore, it is just as important to publish the data and digital tools as it is to publish the articles that set out and discuss the conclusions. Replicating results obtained through software is generally not easy, as the digital world is in constant flux and all software goes from version to version. To lower the barrier to effective replication, we make sure that our data is properly archived and that our software is available as open source in online repositories with versioning. These resources can then be permanently referenced, e.g. by Digital Object Identifiers (DOIs), and can be freely downloaded.

sections.heading: 3.2 Database, website and tools
sections.text: We base our argument on the database of the Eep Talstra Centre for Bible and Computer (ETCBC). A few years ago, this database was put fully online in the form of SHEBANQ (System for HEBrew text: Annotations for Queries and markup) 8. On this website, you can read the full masoretic text (abbreviated as MT) according to the Biblia Hebraica Stuttgartensia9. Linguistic information in the ETCBC database is exposed and users can query the combined information of text and linguistic data. sections.heading: 4.2. A case study: 2 Kings 19-25
sections.text: Now let us take a closer look at the last part of the Book of Kings and its parallel texts. This is a group of interesting chapters, because 2 Kings 19-20 have parallels in Isaiah 37-39, 2 Kings 21-23 have parallels in 2 Chronicles 33-34, and 2 Kings 24-25 have parallels in Jeremiah 52, as can be seen from the chapter comparisons of these books. 19 As in the previous section, we mainly focus on the formal characteristics of textual similarities.

sections.heading: 4.2.1. Visualization of 2 Kings and its parallels
sections.text: First, we found out where all the parallel verses of 2 Kings 19-25 can be found and plotted in the MT. The similarity between parallel passages was based on verses, and the similarity was based on the SET method, and a similarity of more than 60 is considered parallel. Results are shown in Figure 1, parallels concerning 2 Kings 19-25 in the Notebook. The backbone of this figure is formed by Reges _ IIr, and a gray line from this column to one of the other columns indicates a parallel passage. passages with great similarities are associated with darker lines than passages with less similarity. In the illustration, we find the parallel verses in Isaiah, 2 Chronicles, and Jeremiah, but some other passages are found in the books of Exodus, Deuteronomy, Ezekiel, Haggai, and elsewhere in the Book of Kings.

sections.heading: 4.2.3. Different manuscripts of Isaiah
sections.text: The parallels in the Book of Kings and Isaiah, as described in the previous section, can all be found in the MT, but the biblical manuscripts of the Dead Sea Scrolls provide an enormous amount of material to which the MT can be compared. Known as the Great Isaiah Scroll or 1QIsaiah, the manuscript contains more or less the full text of the Book of Isaiah 28. We have made a binary chapter comparison for the full text of the text of Isaiah in the MT and 1QIsaiah. Results can be found in Section 0.1 Results of Notebook 29.
